Investigation of surface plasmons in Kretschmann structure loaded with a silver nano-cube
Xiangxian Wanga,⁎, Xuelin Baia, Zhiyuan Panga, Hua Yanga, Yunping Qib
a School of Science, Lanzhou University of Technology, Lanzhou 730050, China b College of Physics and Electronic Engineering, Northwest Normal University, Lanzhou 730070, China
A R T I C L E I N F O

sections.heading: Keywords:
sections.text:
Surface plasmons Silver nano-cube Electric field enhancement factor
A B S T R A C T
A composite structure based on a Kretschmann structure loaded with silver nano-cube is proposed. A 442-nm laser was used to excite surface plasmons in the composite structure, and the electric field enhancement was numerically simulated using the finite element method. The excitation angles of surface plasmons under conditions of different thicknesses of a PMMA film were obtained by studying the reflection spectrum of the Kretschmann structure. By examining the extinction spectra of silver nano-cubes of different sizes, its optimal size was selected, which is 70 nm. The electric field enhancement factors of the composite structure and the composite PMMA-spaced silver nano-cube and silver film structure were compared in detail. The results show that the coupling of localized surface plasmons and propagating surface plasmons produced by the proposed composite structure mean that its electric field enhancement factor is significantly greater. Moreover, the electric field enhancement factor can be further improved by adding another laser to irradiate the composite structure symmetrically. The high electric field enhancement generated by the composite structure indicates that it has considerable application prospects in surface-enhanced Raman scattering.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Surface plasmons (SPs) are electromagnetic waves that propagate along a metal-dielectric interface [1–3]. SPs may be categorized into two classes: localized surface plasmons (LSPs) that are excited by nanoparticles [4], and propagating surface plasmons (PSPs) excited by grating or prism coupling [5,6]. Owing to the special electric field enhancement effect of SPs, they have important applications in surfaceenhanced Raman scattering (SERS) [7–12], nanolithography [13–15], sensors [16–21], Fano Resonances [22–24], absorption enhancement [25], terahertz oscillations [26–28], and photocatalysis [29–34]. Therefore, researchers have designed a variety of micro- and nanostructures to excite SPs, for example, a single slit with multi-pair groove nanostructure [35], periodically elliptical graphene arrays [36], geometrically symmetric electric split-ring resonators (eSRRs)-shaped graphene arrays [37], two-dimensional (2D) arrays of metallic nanodisk pairs [38], and so on. Apart from electric field enhancement and LSPs or PSPs excited by single structures being observed, composite structures with coupling between LSPs and PSPs can allow higher electric field enhancement factors and wider applicability of the SPs effects. Lagarkov et al. [39] investigated a two-dimensional periodic system of silicon micro-cones, and obtained electric field enhancement at the hot
spot between the gold nanoparticle and silicone cone by a factor of 629. Mehrvar et al. [40] studied nanosphere arrays that provided strong electric field enhancement, and the results indicated that the enhancement factor achieved for the nanorhomb array was a hundred times greater than that of the nanohole array. Yi et al. [41] researched the plasmonic interaction between silver nano-cubes and a silver ground plane with and without a dielectric; their experimental results demonstrated that the composite substrate made from the silver nanocubes and the silver ground plane produced a stronger SERS signal than that of the cubes alone. A composite structure with simultaneously excited LSP and PSP was reported that consisted of a two-dimensional periodic gold nanoparticle array, SiO2 spacer, and gold film; in experiments, strong coupling between the localized and propagating surface plasmons was demonstrated [42]. Furthermore, we theoretically designed a composite structure as a dielectric grating/metal film and a silver nano-cube, and concluded that the electric field enhancement factor was as high as 1.53× 106 [43].
In this letter, we propose a composite structure based on a Kretschmann structure loaded with a silver nano-cube, which could produce a higher electric field enhancement factor than a dielectricspaced composite of a metal nano-cube and metal film. The composite structure based on the Kretschmann structure loaded with the silver nano-cube is potentially useful in SERS substrate applications for ultra-low concentration detection [46].

sections.heading: Theoretical analysis
sections.text:
The composite structure is depicted in Fig. 1a, and consists of prism, index-matching oil, SiO2 substrate, 45-nm-thick silver film, PMMA film, and silver nano-cube. A TM-polarized laser beam with wavelength 442 nm irradiates the silver film through the coupling prism at an incident angle of θsp, which can excite a PSP. The prism, index-matching oil, and SiO2 substrate can be considered as a single entity, and the purpose of our design procedure is to optimize experimental convenience and feasibility. For comparison with a composite structure, Fig. 1b shows a PMMA-spaced silver nano-cube and silver film composite structure. The TM-polarized laser beam with wavelength 442 nm irradiates perpendicularly to this structure. LSP were further excited by exciting the PSP in the composite structure shown in Fig. 1a, while in the composite PMMA-spaced silver nano-cube and silver film structure shown in Fig. 1b, PSP were excited by exciting the LSP. The permittivities of the prism, silver, and PMMA used in the numerical simulations that are described in the following section were 2.1497,
−5.7018+0.7514i [47], and 2.25, respectively.

sections.heading: Simulation results and discussion
sections.text:
Firstly, the parameters of the Kretschmann structure were optimized. Fig. 2a shows the reflection spectra of the Kretschmann structure with different thicknesses of PMMA between 2 and 25 nm; it is apparent that PMMA of different thicknesses corresponds to different excitation angles. The excitation angle increases with the increase of PMMA thickness, and the full width at half maximum also increases.
Fig. 2b shows the extinction spectra for silver nano-cubes of different sizes, as calculated by the finite element method; the size of the silver nano-cube varies from 50 nm to 95 nm, and the increase interval is 5 nm. The optimal size of the silver nano-cube is 70 nm for the condition of 442-nm excitation light. Therefore, we selected the 70-nm silver nano-cube as the size used in subsequent numerical calculations.
The electric field enhancement factor in the proposed composite structure and the composite of PMMA-spaced silver nano-cube and silver film structure was then calculated. The electric field enhancement is defined as the square of the ratio of the electric field intensity to the incident field intensity, that is, |E/E0|2. In the simulation, we defined the interface between the PMMA and the silver film as the XOY plane. First, the electric field distribution of the composite structure illustrated in Fig. 1b was calculated for a PMMA thickness of 12 nm. As shown in Fig. 3a, the maximum electric field enhancement factor with a value of 5.69×104 is located in the hot spot, that is, the upper vertexes of the
silver nano-cube. For comparison, the electric field distribution of the proposed composite structure is shown in Fig. 3b, with the laser beam set to irradiate the structure at an excitation angle θsp of 54.3°. The electric field enhancement factor at the hot spot is as high as 6.45×105, which occurs at the interface of the lower left vertex of the silver nano-cube and the PMMA film. The electric field enhancement factor of the proposed composite structure is approximately 11 times that of the composite PMMA-spaced silver nano-cube and silver film structure. In order to further improve the electric field enhancement
factor, we symmetrically added a laser beam to irradiate the proposed composite structure. As shown in Fig. 3c, it is obvious that the electric field enhancement factor is 2.33× 106, with the hot spot on the interface between the silver nano-cube and the lower vertexes of the PMMA film. The electric field distribution produced by the interference of the surface plasmon is periodic. Therefore, the center of the silver nano-cube is located at the maximum value of the interference field. The hot spots are mainly located in the locations between the bottom vertexes of the silver nano-cube and the PMMA film in the proposed
composite structure. To further investigate and compare the electric field enhancement factors of the abovementioned structures, the relationships between the electric field enhancement factors and the different thicknesses of the PMMA films in these structures are displayed in Fig. 4. The plotted relationship between the electric field enhancement factor and the difference thickness of PMMA of the composite PMMA-spaced silver nano-cube and silver film structure (Yellow diamond line) reveals that as the thickness of the PMMA increases, the electric field enhancement factor first decreases and then increases. The variation of the electric field enhancement factor of the proposed composite structure for a single incident laser beam is the green inverted-triangle line in the figure, and the relationship between the electric field enhancement factor and the different thicknesses of the PMMA in the composite structure upon the addition of a second, symmetric laser beam is plotted as a blue regular-triangle line. Comparing the lines in Fig. 4, it is obvious that the resonance coupling between the LSP and PSP is the strongest when the thickness of the PMMA film is 14 nm, and the maximum electric field enhancement factor of the proposed composite structure for a single laser beam is 1.08×106. The electric field enhancement factor of the proposed composite structure with two laser beams is 3.51×106, which is 3.25 times that of the proposed composite structure with the single laser beam. These results show that the electric field enhancement factor of the composite structure is much higher than that of the composite PMMA-spaced silver nano-cube and silver film structure.
According to the above simulation results, it is clear that the electric field enhancement factor of the composite Kretschmann structure loaded with a silver nano-cube is higher than that of the composite PMMA-spaced silver nano-cube and silver film structure. When the single laser beam irradiates the composite Kretschmann structure loaded with a silver nano-cube at an excitation angle θsp, the PSP of the Kretschmann structure is excited, followed by the LSP of the silver nano-cube. A strong coupling occurs between PSP and LSP produced by the proposed composite structure, and the electric field enhancement factor produced by this strong coupling is high. However, the PSP is further excited by exciting the LSP in the composite PMMA-spaced silver nano-cube and the silver film structure when the laser beam irradiates perpendicularly. Further, the resonant coupling of LSP and PSP produces an electric field enhancement factor. Obviously, the productiveness of PSP to excite LSP is higher than that of LSP to excite PSP. These results show that the electric field enhancement factor of the proposed composite structure is much higher than that of the composite PMMA-spaced silver nano-cube and silver film structure.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text: In this paper, a composite Kretschmann structure loaded with a silver nano-cube is proposed. Because of the strong resonance coupling between the LSP and PSP, a high electric field enhancement factor is obtained for the proposed composite structure. When a TM-polarized laser beam with wavelength 442 nm is used to excite SPs, according to the numerical simulation results, the optimized parameter values are, size of the silver nano-cube=70 nm and thickness of the PMMA film=14 nm. The electric field enhancement factor of the proposed composite structure with one laser beam irradiating is 11 times that of the composite PMMA-spaced silver nano-cube and silver film structure. Furthermore, the electric field enhancement factor of the proposed composite can be enhanced by symmetrically adding another laser beam irradiation. This composite Kretschmann structure loaded with a silver nano-cube will have practical application in surface-enhanced Raman scattering.
